Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Transition from Rifting to Seafloor Spreading at the Western Tip of the Cocos-Nazca Rift
Award.AbstractNarration:
OCE 1558592

Collaborative Research: The Transition from Rifting to Seafloor Spreading at the Western Tip of the Cocos-Nazca Rift


Abstract for posting

A long-standing question in the study of mid-ocean ridges focuses on how they initiate and evolve. Our research cruise to the Galapagos Triple Junction in the eastern equatorial Pacific Ocean will characterize the transition from initial rifting to seafloor spreading, and the associated development of ridge axis segmentation. In this region, the western tip of the Cocos-Nazca Rift is breaking into ~0.5 Ma crust accreted on the east flank of the East Pacific Rise, and each stage in the transition from rifting to magmatic seafloor spreading can be studied. In order to examine along-axis changes as a function of distance from the rift tip, we will collect geophysical data on morphology, gravity and magnetic variations, rock samples for chemical analyses, and water column data for identifying hydrothermal activity. Our findings on oceanic rifting will complement on-going studies of these processes in continental rift settings.

Our study area extends eastward from the site of initial rifting of the Cocos-Nazca spreading center to nucleantion of magmatic spreading at the Hess Deep rift, to full magmatic spreading, thus exhibiting progressive stages in the initiation and development of rifting and segmentation. Multibeam bathymetry, gravity, and magnetic data will be collected to reconstruct the tectonic evolution from initial rifting through seafloor spreading, and in particular, changes in segment and offset characteristics as they develop. Chemical analysis of rock samples collected along the spreading axes and along flow lines will shed light on the evolution of mantle melting and melt delivery systems and their relationship to the tectonic segmentation. Graduate and undergraduate students (Duke and MIT/WHOI), will participate in the cruise and on-shore research, gaining valuable seagoing experience and learning to conduct collaborative research. In addition, we will develop activities based upon this work for use in a yearly science-immersion program for minority, middle school girls.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goal of this project was to study the initiation and evolution of a newly forming mid-ocean ridge: the Cocos-Nazca (C-N) Rift in the eastern equatorial Pacific Ocean. During the first year, we conducted a sea going expedition aboard R/V Sally Ride (Leg 1806) from April 20 to May 26, 2018 (23 science days). Our study extended from the Galapagos Triple Junction region, where the western tip of the C-N spreading center is rifting half-million-year old crust accreted on the east flank of the East Pacific Rise (EPR), eastward through the C-N segments that ultimately merge into the Galapagos Spreading Center. We sought to elucidate the changes in - and the interplay between - tectonic and magmatic processes that occur from initial rifting through full magmatic seafloor spreading, and to investigate the development and evolution of the tectonic and magmatic segmentation characteristics during the transition from slow to intermediate spreading rates.

We collected bathymetric, magnetic, and gravity data covering a V-shaped area extending eastward from the Hess Deep Rift to ~98.5°W and including on- and off-axis terrane not previously surveyed. We also collecting magnetic and gravity data across the Galapagos microplate to understand its initiation and evolution. Rock sampling included a total of 66 dredges (3 empty), dominantly sited along the C-N Rift and adjacent EPR, as well as the Dietz Volcanic Ridge.

Chemical analysis of rock samples revealed that the C-N lavas are unusually depleted in incompatible trace element ratios (e.g., La/SmN as low as 0.38) compared to typical EPR basalts. Similarly depleted values have been found in lavas from some 'leaky' transforms (e.g. Garrett, Siqueiros) and EPR seamounts, commonly associated with transitional or enriched compositions, and are often interpreted as incomplete mixing of diverse mantle melts. Along the C-N rift, however, eruption of only highly depleted to depleted melts suggests an absence of typical source heterogeneity, which may relate to the rift’s proximity to the EPR.  Numerical modeling suggests that melting beneath much of the C-N rift may tap a source previously depleted in early melting pyroxenite veins during melt generation beneath the EPR. While only depleted samples were recovered from the C-N rift, transitional compositions erupt along the Dietz Volcanic Ridge DVR), the southern boundary of the Galapagos microplate. This, coupled with the shallowness of the DVR, supports the theory that the DVR represents a mini hotspot and acted to fix the position of the southern boundary of the Galapagos microplate during its formation.  While the geochemical findings are being prepared for publication, the geophysical data published by Smith et al. (2020) provides a detailed description of the initiation and development this newly forming spreading center, adding to the body of work focused on ridge initiation and development elsewhere. 

Led by scientists from Duke University and the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, our science party included a diverse international group of undergraduate and graduate students and research scientists from Poland, Spain, Russia, the UK and the US.  Support for international participants was provided in part by InterRidge and the University of Leeds. In addition to providing valuable training for students, part of our outreach plan involved yearly participation a hands-on science workshop for local middle school girls (~ 150) called FEMMES (Females Excelling More in Math Engineering and Science).  Over the course of the three years of this project, we reached approximately 400-500 middle school girls. In addition, during the cruise we engaged with the public-at-large through our cruise web site, twitter feed, and Instagram account, and Klein continues to be contacted periodically, often from middle or high school girls. See http://blogs.nicholas.duke.edu/cocosnazca/; https://twitter.com/cocos_cruise/;  www.instagram.com/cocos_cruise/
